section.title: Participle clauses/gerunds (-ing forms)
section.sectiontitle: Use participle clauses as reduced relative clauses. Instead of complete verbs, we use a participle clause.
section.text1: I spoke to the girl who was wearing a white dress.
section.text1a: I spoke to the girl wearing a white dress.
section.text2: I read about a road that was blocked by a fallen tree.
section.text2a: I read about a road blocked by a fallen tree.
section.sectiontitle2: We can use participle clauses for many purposes, e.g. expressing cause, result, conditions, etc.
section.text3: Because he was feeling tired, he went to bed.
section.text4: If you take the motorway, you can get there in one hour.
section.text4a: Taking the motorway, you can get there in one hour.

section.title: <b>Participle clauses/gerunds
section.sectiontitle: We use the -ing form after many conjunctions and prepositions, e.g. before, since, when, once, in spite of, as.
section.text1a: Since becoming a lawyer, he has worked very long hours.
section.text2a: In spite of growing up on the beach, she hated the ocean.
section.sectiontitle2: We can use the -ing form as the subject of a sentence.
section.text4a: Dancing all night is fine when you're young.

section.title: <b>Participle clauses/gerunds
section.sectiontitle: Having + past participle is a special form that shows the cause of a second action (or a sequence of actions).
section.text1: I lost my credit card. I had to call the bank.
section.text1a: Having lost my credit card, I had to call the bank.
section.text2: Johnson broke the world record. Then he immediately retired from athletics.
section.text2a: Having broken the world record, Johnson retired immediately from athletics.
section.sectiontitle2: We often use present and past participles as adjectives.
section.text4: The teacher was shocked by the students' behaviour.
